articles.headline: Amazon Is Cracking Down on Union Organizing, Workers Say
articles.snippet: The company has disciplined union supporters and fired one in recent weeks, ahead of a trial that will weigh their right to interact with co-workers.
articles.abstract: The company has disciplined union supporters and fired one in recent weeks, ahead of a trial that will weigh their right to interact with co-workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than a year and a half after Amazon workers on Staten Island voted to form the company’s first union in the United States, the company appears to be taking a harder line toward labor organizing, disciplining workers and even firing one who had been heavily involved in the union campaign.

articles.headline: Conundrum of Covering Trump Lands at Univision’s Doorstep
articles.snippet: When the U.S.’s largest Spanish-language network ran a friendly interview with the former president, Democrats cried foul. Executives say they’re seeking more balance.
articles.abstract: When the U.S.’s largest Spanish-language network ran a friendly interview with the former president, Democrats cried foul. Executives say they’re seeking more balance.
articles.lead_paragraph: The howls of protest against Univision began as soon as its interview with Donald J. Trump aired. A month later, they still haven’t stopped.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles, Ken Bensinger and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Retail Group Retracts Startling Claim About ‘Organized’ Shoplifting
articles.snippet: The National Retail Federation had said that nearly half of the industry’s $94.5 billion in missing merchandise in 2021 was the result of organized theft. It was likely closer to 5 percent, experts say.
articles.abstract: The National Retail Federation had said that nearly half of the industry’s $94.5 billion in missing merchandise in 2021 was the result of organized theft. It was likely closer to 5 percent, experts say.
articles.lead_paragraph: A national lobbying group has retracted its startling estimate that “organized retail crime” was responsible for nearly half the $94.5 billion in store merchandise that disappeared in 2021, a figure that helped amplify claims that the United States was experiencing a nationwide wave of shoplifting.

articles.headline: Ex-U.S. Ambassador Accused of Being a Cuban Agent Rose From Humble Origins
articles.snippet: Former colleagues are struggling to separate fact from deception as they reconsider Manuel Rocha, who was accused of being a Cuban agent for decades.
articles.abstract: Former colleagues are struggling to separate fact from deception as they reconsider Manuel Rocha, who was accused of being a Cuban agent for decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: The indictment of Manuel Rocha, the former U.S. ambassador accused of working for Cuba’s spy service for decades, has left longtime colleagues struggling to make sense of what was real and what was deception in a life that straddled poverty and privilege.
articles.byline: By Ernesto Londoño, Frances Robles and David C. Adams

articles.headline: U.S. Vetoes Israel-Hamas Cease-Fire Resolution at U.N. Security Council
articles.snippet: The veto came amid a warning that “civil order is breaking down” in Gaza, and a day after the Biden administration warned that Israel’s military had not done enough to reduce harm to civilians.
articles.abstract: The veto came amid a warning that “civil order is breaking down” in Gaza, and a day after the Biden administration warned that Israel’s military had not done enough to reduce harm to civilians.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States on Friday vetoed a United Nations resolution calling for an immediate cease-fire in the Gaza Strip, where Israel has launched hundreds of strikes, relief efforts were faltering and people were growing so desperate for basic necessities that some were stoning and raiding aid convoys.
articles.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi, Michael Levenson, Aaron Boxerman and Victoria Kim

articles.headline: E.U. Agrees on Landmark Artificial Intelligence Rules
articles.snippet: The agreement over the A.I. Act solidifies one of the world’s first comprehensive attempts to limit the use of artificial intelligence.
articles.abstract: The agreement over the A.I. Act solidifies one of the world’s first comprehensive attempts to limit the use of artificial intelligence.
articles.lead_paragraph: European Union policymakers agreed on Friday to a sweeping new law to regulate artificial intelligence, one of the world’s first comprehensive attempts to limit the use of a rapidly evolving technology that has wide-ranging societal and economic implications.

articles.headline: Inside OpenAI’s Crisis Over the Future of Artificial Intelligence
articles.snippet: Split over the leadership of Sam Altman, board members and executives turned on one another. Their brawl exposed the cracks at the heart of the A.I. movement.
articles.abstract: Split over the leadership of Sam Altman, board members and executives turned on one another. Their brawl exposed the cracks at the heart of the A.I. movement.
articles.lead_paragraph: Around noon on Nov. 17, Sam Altman, the chief executive of OpenAI, logged into a video call from a luxury hotel in Las Vegas. He was in the city for its inaugural Formula 1 race, which had drawn 315,000 visitors including Rihanna and Kylie Minogue.
articles.byline: By Tripp Mickle, Cade Metz, Mike Isaac and Karen Weise

articles.headline: Shoppers, Facing Holiday Spending, Turn to Loyalty Programs
articles.snippet: The programs and the incentives that come with them will be critical for retailers hoping to attract cash-strapped customers over the next month.
articles.abstract: The programs and the incentives that come with them will be critical for retailers hoping to attract cash-strapped customers over the next month.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chrissy West is taking a new approach to her Christmas shopping this year. When buying gifts for her family, she plans to finance them by cashing in her Ulta loyalty points.
articles.byline: By Jordyn Holman and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: Fears of a NATO Withdrawal Rise as Trump Seeks a Return to Power
articles.snippet: Current and former European diplomats said there was growing concern a second Trump presidency could mean an American retreat from the continent and a gutting of NATO.
articles.abstract: Current and former European diplomats said there was growing concern a second Trump presidency could mean an American retreat from the continent and a gutting of NATO.
articles.lead_paragraph: For 74 years, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has been America’s most important military alliance. Presidents of both parties have seen NATO as a force multiplier enhancing the influence of the United States by uniting countries on both sides of the Atlantic in a vow to defend one another.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Swan, Charlie Savage and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Stolen Checks Are for Sale Online. We Called Some of the Victims.
articles.snippet: One reason this fraud is rampant: Open forums where anyone can buy checks that thieves have taken from the mail.
articles.abstract: One reason this fraud is rampant: Open forums where anyone can buy checks that thieves have taken from the mail.
articles.lead_paragraph: Our national check-writing habit is turning into an enormous problem.

articles.headline: Mideast War Pushes Companies to Extend Diversity Programs to Faith Groups
articles.snippet: Workers are asking employers to respond to rising Islamophobia and antisemitism. But office discussions about religion are complicated.
articles.abstract: Workers are asking employers to respond to rising Islamophobia and antisemitism. But office discussions about religion are complicated.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Nabeela Elsayed was speaking at a corporate conference several years ago and explained that she would miss the group dinner because she was fasting for Ramadan, she recalls, her manager responded: “Just don’t fast.” Ms. Elsayed, an executive coach who was previously chief operating officer for Walmart Canada, said she had heard many such slights when stepping away during the workday to pray.

articles.headline: Tiny Electric Vehicles Pack a Bigger Climate Punch Than Cars
articles.snippet: Two- and three-wheeled vehicles, used by billions of people, are moving away from fossil fuels to batteries faster than cars in countries that have made the energy transition a priority.
articles.abstract: Two- and three-wheeled vehicles, used by billions of people, are moving away from fossil fuels to batteries faster than cars in countries that have made the energy transition a priority.
articles.lead_paragraph: Big Oil faces a tiny foe on the streets of Asia and Africa. The noisy, noxious vehicles that run on two and three wheels, carrying billions of people daily, are quietly going electric — in turn knocking down oil demand by one million barrels a day this year.
articles.byline: By Somini Sengupta, Abdi Latif Dahir, Alex Travelli and Clifford Krauss

articles.headline: We Can’t Stop Writing Paper Checks. Thieves Love That.
articles.snippet: Although check use has declined in the last couple of decades, check fraud has risen sharply, creating a problem for banks — and customers trying to pay their bills.
articles.abstract: Although check use has declined in the last couple of decades, check fraud has risen sharply, creating a problem for banks — and customers trying to pay their bills.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Pam Berns mailed a few checks to pay bills, she had no idea such a routine task would throw her small publishing business into chaos.

articles.headline: Penn’s Leadership Resigns Amid Controversies Over Antisemitism
articles.snippet: The president, Elizabeth Magill, and the chairman of the board of trustees, Scott L. Bok, are leaving after intense pressure from donors, politicians and alumni.
articles.abstract: The president, Elizabeth Magill, and the chairman of the board of trustees, Scott L. Bok, are leaving after intense pressure from donors, politicians and alumni.
articles.lead_paragraph: The president of the University of Pennsylvania, M. Elizabeth Magill, resigned on Saturday, four days after she appeared before Congress and appeared to evade the question of whether students who called for the genocide of Jews should be punished.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Saul, Alan Blinder, Anemona Hartocollis and Maureen Farrell

articles.headline: Gaza War Has Buoyed Egypt’s Leader Ahead of Presidential Vote
articles.snippet: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt grew increasingly unpopular amid a deep economic crisis. But the war in neighboring Gaza has given him a vital role on the international stage.
articles.abstract: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt grew increasingly unpopular amid a deep economic crisis. But the war in neighboring Gaza has given him a vital role on the international stage.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi of Egypt woke up on Oct. 7 remarkably unpopular for someone considered a shoo-in for a third term — guaranteed by his authoritarian grip on the country to dominate elections that begin on Sunday, but badly damaged by a slow-motion economic collapse.

articles.headline: ‘Buying Quiet’: Inside the Israeli Plan That Propped Up Hamas
articles.snippet: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu gambled that a strong Hamas (but not too strong) would keep the peace and reduce pressure for a Palestinian state.
articles.abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu gambled that a strong Hamas (but not too strong) would keep the peace and reduce pressure for a Palestinian state.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just weeks before Hamas launched the deadly Oct. 7 attacks on Israel, the head of Mossad arrived in Doha, Qatar, for a meeting with Qatari officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: The Guns Were Said to Be Destroyed. Instead, They Were Reborn.
articles.snippet: Communities across the U.S. are fueling a secondary arms market by giving seized and surrendered guns to disposal services that destroy one part and resell the rest.
articles.abstract: Communities across the U.S. are fueling a secondary arms market by giving seized and surrendered guns to disposal services that destroy one part and resell the rest.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Flint, Mich., announced in September that 68 assault weapons collected in a gun buyback would be incinerated, the city cited its policy of never reselling firearms.

articles.headline: The Book World Still Isn’t Diverse. Dhonielle Clayton Is Trying to Change That.
articles.snippet: Her solution? A packaging business that sells ideas for commercial genre fiction featuring characters from broadly diverse backgrounds.
articles.abstract: Her solution? A packaging business that sells ideas for commercial genre fiction featuring characters from broadly diverse backgrounds.
articles.lead_paragraph: One evening this fall, a crowd of writers and publishing professionals mingled in a speakeasy-style lounge in Midtown Manhattan. The party, hosted by a new company called Electric Postcard Entertainment, was the kind of lavish affair that’s become rare for the book business in an era of corporate consolidation and cuts.

articles.headline: Is Anti-Zionism Always Antisemitic? A Fraught Question for the Moment.
articles.snippet: From the halls of Congress to America’s streets and universities, a once largely academic issue has roiled national discourse, inciting accusations of bigotry and countercharges of bullying.
articles.abstract: From the halls of Congress to America’s streets and universities, a once largely academic issue has roiled national discourse, inciting accusations of bigotry and countercharges of bullying.
articles.lead_paragraph: The brutal shedding of Jewish blood on Oct. 7, followed by Israel’s relentless military assault on Gaza, has brought a fraught question to the fore in a moment of surging bigotry and domestic political gamesmanship: Is anti-Zionism by definition antisemitism?

articles.headline: As Fury Erupts Over Campus Antisemitism, Conservatives Seize the Moment
articles.snippet: Republicans have been attacking elite universities for years. After a tense congressional hearing last week, many on the left are joining them.
articles.abstract: Republicans have been attacking elite universities for years. After a tense congressional hearing last week, many on the left are joining them.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, conservatives have struggled to persuade American voters that the left-wing tilt of higher education is not only wrong but dangerous. Universities and their students, they’ve argued, have been increasingly clenched by suffocating ideologies — political correctness in one decade, overweening “social justice” in another, “woke-ism” most recently — that shouldn’t be dismissed as academic fads or harmless zeal.

articles.headline: Shari Redstone Is Said to Be in Talks to Sell Her Stake in Media Empire
articles.snippet: Ms. Redstone waged a bitter battle for control of National Amusements, the parent company of MTV, CBS and the Paramount movie studio. Now, she’s considering a sale.
articles.abstract: Ms. Redstone waged a bitter battle for control of National Amusements, the parent company of MTV, CBS and the Paramount movie studio. Now, she’s considering a sale.
articles.lead_paragraph: The media mogul Shari Redstone is in talks to sell a controlling stake in National Amusements, the parent company of the sprawling news and entertainment empire that includes the Paramount movie studio, CBS and MTV, according to three people familiar with the talks.

articles.headline: To Handle a Surge of Illegal Crossings, Border Officials Stop Legal Ones
articles.snippet: Some border communities in the U.S. and Mexico are suddenly cut off from each other after a border crossing closed to cope with large numbers of migrants.
articles.abstract: Some border communities in the U.S. and Mexico are suddenly cut off from each other after a border crossing closed to cope with large numbers of migrants.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like many people in the tiny town of Why, Ariz., Stephanie Fierro’s life revolves around the nearby border crossing. She works at a roadside café serving enchiladas to American tourists passing through on their way to beach resorts in Mexico. Her husband, a Mexican citizen, lives on the other side.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy, Miriam Jordan and Rebecca Noble

articles.headline: Ohtani’s Contract Goes Beyond Dollars and Sense
articles.snippet: The Los Angeles Dodgers are betting $700 million that Shohei Ohtani can deliver championships and help increase revenue. But the economics of sports can be fickle.
articles.abstract: The Los Angeles Dodgers are betting $700 million that Shohei Ohtani can deliver championships and help increase revenue. But the economics of sports can be fickle.
articles.lead_paragraph: Japanese baseball players are taught to keep a low profile and let their performances do the talking. Yet for more than a decade, Shohei Ohtani has been willing to make waves.

articles.headline: Gazans Mass at Border for Safety, but Find Only More Peril
articles.snippet: As Israeli forces pound Gaza, the area where Palestinians can seek shelter is shrinking, raising concerns that they could be forced into Egypt.
articles.abstract: As Israeli forces pound Gaza, the area where Palestinians can seek shelter is shrinking, raising concerns that they could be forced into Egypt.
articles.lead_paragraph: The last point of refuge for Palestinians fleeing from Israel’s relentless siege of Gaza is collapsing under the weight of tens of thousands of people seeking food and shelter, stirring fears of a potential mass displacement into Egypt, United Nations officials warned on Sunday.
articles.byline: By Ameera Harouda, Ben Hubbard and Vivian Nereim

articles.headline: Corporate America Is Testing the Limits of Its Pricing Power
articles.snippet: Firms may struggle to keep profits up if demand slows, but so far they are finding ways to keep margins wide.
articles.abstract: Firms may struggle to keep profits up if demand slows, but so far they are finding ways to keep margins wide.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alexander MacKay coleads the Pricing Lab at Harvard Business School, a research center devoted to studying how companies set prices. Since the pandemic, he has watched how businesses have become more willing to experiment with what they charge their customers.
articles.byline: By Jason Karaian, Jeanna Smialek and Joe Rennison

articles.headline: Biden Administration Chooses Military Supplier for First Chips Act Grant
articles.snippet: The award, which will go to BAE Systems, is part of a new government program aimed at creating a more secure supply of semiconductors.
articles.abstract: The award, which will go to BAE Systems, is part of a new government program aimed at creating a more secure supply of semiconductors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Biden administration announced on Monday that BAE Systems, a defense contractor, will receive the first federal grant from a new program aimed at shoring up American manufacturing of critical semiconductors.

articles.headline: What Ails Offshore Wind: Supply Chains, Ships and Interest Rates
articles.snippet: Government officials and energy developers misjudged the difficulty of building huge clean energy projects in the United States, which has built very few of them.
articles.abstract: Government officials and energy developers misjudged the difficulty of building huge clean energy projects in the United States, which has built very few of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: A few years ago, interest in offshore wind energy was so strong that developers proposed spending tens of billions of dollars to plunk hundreds of turbines the size of skyscrapers in the Atlantic Ocean from Maine to Virginia.
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn, Stanley Reed and Brad Plumer

articles.headline: The Power Vacuum at the Top of the Crypto Industry
articles.snippet: A year ago, Sam Bankman-Fried and Changpeng Zhao ran two of the largest crypto companies. As they grapple with legal woes, others are jockeying to lead the industry’s next chapter.
articles.abstract: A year ago, Sam Bankman-Fried and Changpeng Zhao ran two of the largest crypto companies. As they grapple with legal woes, others are jockeying to lead the industry’s next chapter.
articles.lead_paragraph: The price of Bitcoin is surging again. Major financial firms are showing renewed interest in digital currencies. And crypto fanatics are celebrating the end of a long period of depressed prices and business collapses.

articles.headline: Did Army Blast Exposure Play Role in Maine Gunman’s Rampage?
articles.snippet: Medical scientists and the military are looking into whether Robert Card’s psychological collapse was linked to brain damage from his role as a grenade instructor.
articles.abstract: Medical scientists and the military are looking into whether Robert Card’s psychological collapse was linked to brain damage from his role as a grenade instructor.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a 40-year-old Army Reservist named Robert Card went on a shooting spree in Lewiston, Maine, in October, his community grasped for answers.

articles.headline: Record Rent Burdens Batter Low-Income Life
articles.snippet: More tenants than ever spend half or more of their income for shelter, leaving less for everything else, taking an emotional toll and leaving some without a place to call their own.
articles.abstract: More tenants than ever spend half or more of their income for shelter, leaving less for everything else, taking an emotional toll and leaving some without a place to call their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: To understand how rising rents punish families of modest means, look no further than the queen-size bed that Jessica Jones and her three children share in her mother’s living room, where each night brings a squirming, turning tussle for space in a house with no privacy.
